body:
I hope my C isn't awful :sweat_smile: 

My only concern is that the error message for me doesn't show the caret (^) indicator of where exactly an error might be (maybe because it's on a newline below it?)

~I was also unsure about convention for allocations failing (hence the comments...)~ Linter warned me about using xstr(n)dup

comment_data.body:
You don't need to initialize with a string here since the `switch` has a default case

```suggestion
  const char *msg;
```
40? Just a bit of extra characters?
Hm 20 proved not to be enough though
If you don't know the number then just give it a big one. IOSIZE should do.
My comment was more about giving 40 a name, not about the specific value. A named constant would help to see what it is doing.
For error strings we typically use the same constant as we don't need to optimise for memory along an error path.

Could we in a follow-up PR forward a table to Lua to account for possible pre-processing of the query source? Lua could subtract lines that come from `; inherit` or forward to a different file in case the error is caused by a `inherit` directive?

Anyways not directly related to this PR... Great work!

comment_regular_data.body: Can you show a screenshot of (or copy&paste) the new error message?

Is it hard to write tests for this? There are many cases. And tests would make it obvious what the messages will look like (I'm curious about why newline is used in some cases but not others). `helpers.pcall_err()` will be useful.

See [test/functional/example_spec.lua](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/test/functional/example_spec.lua) for example. You can [run the test](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/test/README.md#running-tests) like this:

    TEST_FILE=test/functional/example_spec.lua make functionaltest

We should also add these errors to `messages` somehow. The current virtual text is virtually unreadable.

A simpler alternative is to replace the end-of-line virtual text by a virtual line, either above -- if possible -- or below the first (visible?) line.

We should also consider upstreaming the query healthcheck from nvim-treesitter.

The virtual_text errors are just a consequence of the queries running inside decoration provider callbacks.

We need to revive #19814 so errors are just printed normally, but in a way to not completly clobber nvim since the errors are triggered on every line.
To be clear, those aren't blockers for this PR , right?

No, but a _useful_ way of exposing these errors is sorely needed. Upstreaming the checkhealth is probably the simplest (just a simple `pcall` of `vim.treesitter.query.get` of all queries in runtimepath and either print "all queries OK" or just surface the error suffices).

But this change is of course a big improvement already and will be helpful for `nvim-treesitter` (as soon as that is updated to account to the new multiline error message).

Here's how the new error looks, by the way:
```
E5108: Error executing lua /usr/local/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/query.lua:273: Query error at 3:2. Invalid node type dentifier)
```

So suggestions: 

1. add quotes around the node type to make it clear what the verbatim node is;
2. there seems to be an off-by-one error, since the opening paren is missing but the closing paren is shown (the full -- deliberately wrong -- node is `(dentifier)`).

> there seems to be an off-by-one error, since the opening paren is missing but the closing paren is shown.

is the `dentifier` perhaps also another off-by-one error? or just copy paste error?

> Here's how the new error looks, by the way:
> 
> ```
> E5108: Error executing lua /usr/local/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/query.lua:273: Query error at 3:2. Invalid node type dentifier)
> ```
> 
> So suggestions:
> 
> 1. add quotes around the node type to make it clear what the verbatim node is;
> 2. there seems to be an off-by-one error, since the opening paren is missing but the closing paren is shown (the full -- deliberately wrong -- node is `(dentifier)`).

Think that was from 20 extra bytes not being enough to hold the msg, 40 should be fine

I'll see if I can add tests but I might need some help there..

Here's what it looks like for me now (node quoted w/ extra room)
![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/29718261/e5226673-54b4-4b5f-aa13-0a39f138de1c)

> (I'm curious about why newline is used in some cases but not others).

Those are for specific recognizable nodes/fields/captures that are impossible, of which they are displayed right after then. The others don't have that
I wouldn't bother with a screen test and just use `exec_lua` with `pcall` and avoid using the highlighter. Look at `parser_spec.lua` on how to create a raw parser.
Oh yeah, that's much better. Now all that's left is fixing multiline errors getting cut off (and so do quotes at the end of the string..?)
We have a leak: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/actions/runs/5972317508/job/16202644648#step:12:5744
I thought it came from not freeing the return value of `query_err_string`, so I freed it but that wasn't it. Not sure what it could be..

I've pushed some fixups that might fix the leak.

First fixup stack allocates the error instead of heap allocating.

Second fixup frees a pointer before allocating into it.

Whoops, was maybe a bit too quick in approving. Is it intended that the error message contains the full query (not just the line, but all further -- unrelated -- patterns)?

If so, maybe it would be better to truncate at the first empty line?
No. It is only supposed to show the offending line.
Definitely not what happens for me. (Use nvim-treesitter/main, install the Lua parser, edit the Lua query to make one node invalid, open a Lua file.)

Seem to work fine for me?

![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/7904185/142c5ee8-cd45-4b22-8cf7-ca2d4782949b)
and so on and so forth (those are the decorator messages)
Ok. I'll try and fix
I don't get the virtual text at all; just the decoration provider error `:message` What am I doing wrong?

Actually yeah, I think this is a problem with the query linter:

```lua
  local node_text = vim.treesitter.get_node_text(node, buf):gsub('\n', ' ')
  --- @type string
  local message = lint .. ': ' .. node_text
```

Yeah, your screenshot works in the Nvim runtime, but not in other query files. 

(The decoration provider error is still a red wall of text.)
Are you sure the problem is because of this change?
Ah, ok I see. Not sure why this is happening.

So there are two things going on:

1. If I edit a query in Nvim's `runtime` to introduce an error, I get _additional_ diagnostics (in addition to the query linter) showing -- as you said and your screenshot showed -- the offending line. This additional diagnostic is absent in other query files on `rtp`. 
(Actually, I prefer that; the additional diagnostic message doesn't offer any additional information, as the query linter already indicates the exact point of error using diagnostics...)

2. The error message from the decoration provider now (always) contains the offending query, but it seems to print the full `IOSIZE`, not just the wrong pattern. (Missing a truncation at empty lines, I'd say.)

> (Actually, I prefer that; the additional diagnostic message doesn't offer any additional information, as the query linter already indicates the exact point of error using diagnostics...)

The query linter should be simplified now.
Sure, but I still prefer the current query linter diagnostic over the new "query error message" diagnostic (too much redundant information)
Do you want to revert the PR entirely or shall I fix the issue? I thought this is what you wanted.

> Do you want to revert the PR entirely 

Of course not; I'm sorry if I gave that impression.

> or shall I fix the issue? I thought this is what you wanted.

It is; I'm just trying (but failing) to give constructive suggestions on what behavior I'd prefer to see (concise diagnostic message in the linter diagnostic, regardless of where it's coming from) -- if that is reasonably doable, otherwise no biggie.

And, again: there are two (unrelated?) issues here; my issue 1 (query linter) is harmless and not a priority and my primary concern is about issue 2.

Yup, that fixes my original issue! Now the error message should be much more useful; I look forward to better bug reports in nvim-treesitter ;)

(Query linter improvements would be a nice follow-up for interested people -- @MariaSolOs ? ;) -- but not at all a priority.)

@clason I'm humbled to be pinged  

I can investigate further. By looking at this PR though I wonder if there's some code here that could be shared with the query linter?
Yes, that's the idea -- or rather, the query linter can make use of the errors that this code already generates directly (with some postprocessing, ideally, to strip redundant information).
@clason got it! I'll look into it (although now I'm down a rabbit hole because of #24968 )
Sure; that does look rather higher priority...

> Sure; that does look rather higher priority...

Oh I actually have no idea of how to fix it lol Im just deeply analyzing my config to see which plugin broke because of #24824 so that I can provide more context.

> Yes, that's the idea -- or rather, the query linter can make use of the errors that this code already generates directly (with some postprocessing, ideally, to strip redundant information).

Okay, baby steps: #24976

The query linter is already using this code BTW.

EDIT: I got too excited, the issue is with the query linter just showing the first line of the diagnostics.
